title: On an analytic approach to the Fatou conjecture

items.abstract: This chapter studies perturbations of polynomials and rational functions with several (possibly, not all) summable critical points. It proves that there exists an r-dimensional manifold Δ‎ in an appropriate space containing f (a polynomial or a rational function which has r summable critical points) such that for every smooth curve in Δ‎ through f, the ratio between parameter and dynamical derivatives along forward iterates of at least one of these summable points tends to a non-zero number. In doing so the chapter establishes a precise form of this relation for rational maps with one critical point satisfying the summability condition (certain expansion rate assumption along the critical orbit). This result brings to a natural general form many previously known special cases studied over the years.
title: Perturbations of weakly expanding critical orbits

items.abstract:
<jats:p>We study the problem of the existence of wild attractors for critical circle coverings with Fibonacci dynamics. This is known to be related to the drift for the corresponding fixed points of renormalization. The fixed point depends only on the order of the critical point <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline1" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\ell$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula> and its drift is a number <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline2" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\unicode[STIX]{x1D717}(\ell )$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula> which is finite for each finite <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline3" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\ell$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula>. We show that the limit <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline4" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\unicode[STIX]{x1D717}(\infty ):=\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty }\unicode[STIX]{x1D717}(\ell )$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula> exists and is finite. The finiteness of the limit is in a sharp contrast with the case of Fibonacci unimodal maps. Furthermore, <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline5" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\unicode[STIX]{x1D717}(\infty )$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula> is expressed as a contour integral in terms of the limit of the fixed points of renormalization when <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline6" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\ell \rightarrow \infty$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula>. There is a certain paradox here, since this dynamical limit is a circle homeomorphism with the golden mean rotation number whose own drift is <jats:inline-formula>
                  <jats:alternatives>
                     <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0143385716000109_inline7" xlink:type="simple" />
                     <jats:tex-math>$\infty$</jats:tex-math>
                  </jats:alternatives>
               </jats:inline-formula> for topological reasons.</jats:p>
title: Limit drift
